Description: Bowl of Nile silt pottery with flat base; sides widen to everted rim. Exterior and inside of rim are coated with red slip, burnished and decorated with motifs in white paint. On the exterior, two concentric lines mark the junction between the rim and the body, below are three stylized representations of hippopotami, their curved incisors shown, ears and eyes indicated by small triangular protrusions. Two face right, one to the left. The interior body decoration differs on all three. Between them are double chevrons that may indicate water or vegetation. The interior of the rim is decorated with groups of five short strokes.
Curator's comments: Lines style suggests the vessel may originate from Naqada. White cross-lined ware of Petrie’s Corpus of Prehistoric Pottery (1921) Published: A Scharff, Some Prehistoric Vases in the British Museum and Remarks on Egyptian Prehistory, JEA 14 (1928), p. 261-2; fig. 1; pl. xxiv.2; A Behrmann, Das Nilpferd in der Vorstellungswelt der alten Aegypter. Teil 1, Katalog. (Frankfort, 1989), doc. 24b. G. Graff, Les peintures sur vases de Naqada I–Naqada II: Nouvelle approche sémiologique de l’iconographie prédynastique, Leuven (2009), cat. no. 93.
